user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_register:
```c
int metal_irq_register(int irq,
		       metal_irq_handler irq_handler,
		       void *arg)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	struct metal_irq *irq_data;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	if (cntr->irq_register != NULL) {
		return cntr->irq_register(cntr, irq, irq_handler, arg);
	}
	if (cntr->irqs == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_data = &cntr->irqs[irq - cntr->irq_base];
	irq_data->hd = irq_handler;
	irq_data->arg = arg;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
irq_data = &cntr->irqs[irq - cntr->irq_base];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — Rule 21.17 is not violated. The fragment does not call any of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17, so that rule cannot be triggered. (Note: the statement can still produce an out‑of‑bounds array access if irq is outside the valid range for cntr->irqs — e.g. if cntr->irq_base == 32 and cntr->irqs has length 8, then irq == 40 yields irq - irq_base == 8 and &cntr->irqs[8] is out of bounds — but that is a general bounds issue, not a violation of Rule 21.17.)
